Options.Value: Cozy
Soothing
Distressing
Comfortable

Question 1.Question:
Reading this passage carefully answer the questions that follow.

PASSAGE 1

Okoli bought his five-shilling postal order, registered his pools coupon and emerged from the post office feeling as he had felt for the past ten years that the world be kind to him. But he was not happy. While waiting in the queue, another customer had told him of a friend who had invested one thousand naira (# 1000) and won thousands. ‘One thousand Naira’, he said to himself. He smiled a smile of difference mixed with optimism. Some passersby noted a smile and thinking was for them, but Okoli nicknamed ‘Time up’ by his friends of the Government department where he worked, did not notice. His thoughts were engaged in contemplating the vagaries of that mysterious god, football pools. He came to the bus-stop and look a little wistfully at a standing vehicle. He would have like to go by it, his home was a mile away and the sun eagerly pricked his head, but his salary did not allow for casual expenses. He therefore, walked home. Okoli took off his workday cloths and changed into brown Wrapper and singlet. Then he set about boiling water for his ‘garri’ ‘No impossible’, he murmured to himself; to gamble on a grand scale? He unlocked a drawer set in the table and slipped out a bank account book. He opened it. His assets stood at exactly one thousand naira (# 1000). A coincidence?

But it might an omen. In the newspaper his stars for the week had said ‘Do not be afraid to take a chance’. Why should his credit stand at exactly the figure the other customer had mentioned? But one might fail even with one thousand Naira. Suppose he failed? He had responsibilities, his father and mother struggling against a perverse land which yearly failed to yield them enough to eat… memories of that land had hunted him forcing him to place a barrier between himself and luxuries.

Adapted from Fagbemi J.A.O et al (1998). Integrated

English Book 3, Ibadan University Press Limited

From the passage Okoli’s living conditions could best be described as
Question 1.Explanation:
This can be seen in paragraph 1, sentences 8 through 11.

‘He came to the bus-stop and look a little wistfully at a standing vehicle. He would have like to go by it, his home was a mile away and the sun eagerly pricked his head, but his salary did not allow for casual expenses. He therefore, walked home. Okoli took off his workday cloths and changed into brown Wrapper and singlet. Then he set about boiling water for his ‘garri’.

Options.Value: Affluence
Prosperity
Reputation
Chance

Question 3.Explanation: An omen is something which signifies a good or evil event or circumstance in the future.

Question 6.Question:
PASSAGE 2

In a parliamentary democracy elections are held periodically to elect a new government. This arrangement ensures that no party has 6 [A. Monopoly B. Majority C. Right D. Knowledge] of power in a country where parliamentary democracy is practiced, the country is divided into ……………… 7 ……………… [A. Regions B. Wards C. Constituencies D. District], each returning one candidate. Long before the election day, political parties engage in all kinds of activities. These activities strengthen ------- 8 ------- [A. Inter-party B. Ultra-party C. Intra-party D. Extra-party] harmony and also define more sharply the focus of the parties. On election day, only those person who are duty ……………. 9 …………… [A. Commissioned B. Enrolled C. Registered D. Taxed] and own voter’s card can vote. To facilitate the voting process, polling booths are made easily accessible to the voters. At the end of the voting, the ------ 10 ------ [A. Ballot box B. Printed papers C. Particulars D. Ballot papers] are counted. When the counting is over the party which get more ………… 11 ……………. [A. Members B. Boxes C. Votes D. Counts] forms the government. A candidate who fails to win a certain percentage of the votes loses his or her ……………… 12 ……………… [A. Right B. Deposit C. Party D. Supporters]. Sometimes the opposition parties accuse the government of ……………… 13 ………………… [A. Holding B. Postponing C. Party D. Controlling] the election in order to retain power… such an accusation usually generates ………… 14 …………… [A. Fear B. Trouble C. Enmity D. Violence] destruction of lives and property. In spite of these ugly side effects of party politics, parliamentary ……………… 15 ………… [A. Rule B. Party C. Election D. Voting] remains a better and more preferred way of electing a new government.

Adapted from: Addo I. B. et al (1978), Objective English Lagos Thomas Nelson Nig) Ltd

Question 6.Explanation: Where there are no elections to change the people in governance, this means government powers would be exclusively and continuously concentrated in one party, which is a practice in contrast with democracy.

Options.Value: Regions
Wards
Constituencies
Districts

Members B. Boxes C. Votes D. Counts] forms the government. A candidate who fails to win a certain percentage of the votes loses his or her ……………… 12 ……………… [A. Right B. Deposit C. Party D. Supporters]. Sometimes the opposition parties accuse the government of ……………… 13 ………………… [A. Holding B. Postponing C. Party D. Controlling] the election in order to retain power… such an accusation usually generates ………… 14 …………… [A. Fear B. Trouble C. Enmity D. Violence] destruction of lives and property. In spite of these ugly side effects of party politics, parliamentary ……………… 15 ………… [A. Rule B. Party C. Election D. Voting] remains a better and more preferred way of electing a new government.

Adapted from: Addo I. B. et al (1978), Objective English Lagos Thomas Nelson Nig) Ltd

Question 32.Question:

Question 33.Question:

Question 34.Question:
Choose the option opposite in meaning to the word or phrase in italics

Question 35.Question:
Choose the option opposite in meaning to the word or phrase in italics

Question 36.Question:

Question 43.Question:
Choose the option that best completes the gap(s)

The …… on the missing child ……. got the police as expected
Question 43.Explanation: Information is an uncountable noun. This means it is considered singular and agrees with singular verbs (has).

Make
Made
Making

Question 44.Question:
Choose the option that best completes the gap(s)

Snakes and ladders always …… me happy these days
Question 44.Explanation: Though snakes and ladders are two words, they form the name of one game. Thus, they are considered singular which should naturally agree with a singular verb ‘makes’.

Options.Value: For
On
In
By

Question 45.Question:
Choose the option that best completes the gap(s).

Garba acquiesced …… their decision.
Question 45.Explanation: Acquiesced means to rest satisfied or apparently satisfied or to rest without opposition and discontent (usually implying previous opposition or discontent). It is followed by ‘n’, sometimes also by ‘with’ and ‘to’

Options.Value: Know/can
Knew/could
Knew/can
Know/could

Question 46.Question:
Choose the option that best completes the gap(s).

If he ……………… French he …………………… go to France
Question 46.Explanation: He, being a singular pronoun can only be used with a singular verb, in this case ‘knows’ in the present tense. Since there isn’t knows, knew is also appropriate. Knew indicates past tense, thus it is only appropriate to use could (past) and not can (present).

Options.Value: Wouldn’t she
Doesn’t she
Won’t she
Didn’t she

Question 47.Question:
Choose the option that best completes the gap(s).

She said you would eat there, …………. ?
Question 47.Explanation: Sentences with lexical or main verb usually form their question tags with the verb o in its various forms (do, does, did)

Options.Value: A two hour break
A two – hour break
A two – hours break
A two hours break

Question 48.Question:
Choose the option that best completes the gap(s).

The delegates were given …………
Question 48.Explanation: The indefinite article ‘a’ makes the succeeding word an adjective and no longer a noun. Thus, ‘two-hour’ now qualities break and cannot be put in the plural form since. It is only when it functions as a noun that it can be plural.

Options.Value: Wish
Wishes
Wishing
Wished

Question 49.Question:
Choose the option that best completes the gap(s).

Amina ……………… she were a beauty queen
Question 49.Explanation: ‘Were’ is used when referring to a present situation that is a fantasy that is where, that describes the situation the way you want it to be, not the way it really is. Emphasis is on present situation which is expressed with a present tense like wishes.

Options.Value: To being
Been
Being
To been

……………… a good boy, he was given a prize
Question 50.Explanation: Being is a verb used to express something that is still in existence.
